Now we have Mantel and
Haenszel who developed in 1859,

the log-rank test,
which is as we'll see,

is kind of the analogy
t-test for survival data.

So we know how to treat,
how to look at one sample,
how to summarize it.

Now let's move up
to two samples,
the so-called log-rank test.

So, again, we're looking
at the brain cancer data
and we have males and females.

We want to compare
their survival.

Well, let's start with
the Kaplan-Meier curves.
Here they are.

Blue is female
and green is male.

And it looks like there's a
slight advantage for females
here.

The question is, is
this significant?

We've only got 88
patients, so we

don't know whether this is
actually a real effect or just
maybe within the noise.

So yes, females seem to fare a
little better up to 50 months,

but then both the curves
level off around 50%.

How can we carry out a test
of the two survival curves?
Again, it looks like--

when we hear two samples,
we think of t-test,

but again, the censoring
creates a complication.

So to overcome the
challenge, we'll

conduct what's called
a log-rank test.

And log-rank test, actually it
has the same kind of structure

as Kaplan-Meier It's
going to proceed,

it's going to sum up things
over the failure times.

So let's call the unique
failure times or death
times d1 through dk.

Let rk be the number of
patients at risk at dk,

and qk the number of
patients who died at dk.

And the number at
risk at dk, we'll

call r1k and r2k
in the two groups,
in this case, males and females.

So Rob, the rk is the number of
patients who died at time dk,

so you're assuming that
more than one person can
die at these time?
I think you said r--
rk?
rk is the number--
at a risk.

And qk, right? qk is the
number who died at dk.

So it is possible some
studies, especially

if the time is sort of measured
discretely, maybe not by days,

by months, you can have
more than one patient
dying at a given time.
I see.

In the simplest
case, qk will be 1.
Yeah.

Basically, but the
log-rank test can

easily can seamlessly
handle the case

where there's tied
survival times.
OK.

And this just says the total
number of patients at risk

are called rk, and
the whom who died, qk.

So what I just said is we
summarize in this table,

here's the two groups,
say males and females,
here's the number that died.

Again, normally one
of these will be a 1

and the other will be a 0,
but it's possible to have--

This is a special little table
just for the death time at dk?
Exactly.
Right.

So we're looking at the
whole sort of process,

but it's a cross-section
saying, OK, at one time, dk,
this is what we see.

And we're going to have
such a table for each dk.

And we said this already,
if the death time is unique,

then one of these is a
1 and the other is a 0.
OK.

So how do we use this table now
to construct a test statistic

to test whether the two
groups are the same,
the survival is the same?

Well, in general, if you
have a random variable

x and you want to test whether
the mean of x is 0, what you do

is you take x and you
center it by the expectation

of x under the null
hypothesis, H0,

and you divide by its
standard deviation.

So the x here we're
going to use is

we're going to use the sum
of the number of people that
died in the top-left table.

In other words, if
we go back here,

if group 1 is much worse
than group 2 in survival,

we expect to see a lot of
ones here and a lot of zeros

here, and vice
versa for group 2.

So you want to see whether
the total number of people

who died in group
1 at each reset

is at large compared to
what we expect it to be.

If they had the
same survival rate.
Exactly.

So this gets a
little complicated,

and the details are in the
text, but essentially we're
going to sum up over resets.

The number in the
top-left corner,

that's the number that
died in group 1, minus

what we'd expect to see if
the two groups were the same,

divided by its
standard deviation.

And what we expect to see
the two groups are the same

is just the total
number at risk times

the proportion that
were in group 1.

So r1k is the total number
at risk in the first group--
Exactly.

--but the proportion,
it's the merged groups.

it's the total deaths
irrespective of group,

so that's the
proportion overall,

and so you want to see if it's
just divided up proportionally.
Exactly.
Yeah.

And that nasty
thing in the bottom
is the standard deviation?
Yes.
The variance, yeah.

The details of which
are in the book.

We don't need to bore
you with this right now.

And then it's summed
over all the death times?
Exactly.
Yeah.

On the average is the number
of people we see in group 1

that die, is it more or less
than we'd expect if the two
groups were the same.

And as is always the case, it's
often the case in statistics

when one form is a normalized
test statistic, what

you do is you say, well, if
the sample size is large,

this is going to be
approximately normal 0 or 1
standard normal distribution.

So we can look at
a normal table,

we can compare the
W to a normal table

and determine what we're seeing
is a departure large enough

that we would or would
not expect it by chance.
And we get p-value from that.
OK.
OK, let's see what it does.
Baa!
Baa!
Baa!
Well, not too exciting.

Log-rank gave a W of 1.2 and
with a corresponding two-sided
p-value of 0.2.

Why are we using a two-sided
p-value here, Trevor?
Oh.
It's a surprise question.
Statistics 101.

Well, we'd be equally
surprised if the male survival

time was worse than the
females or vice versa.

And so we don't want to look at
the result and then just test
what we see.

Our priori, we we'd be
surprised either direction.

So it makes the test more
objective, more unbiased,

otherwise we'd be favoring
as a null hypothesis is, OK.
Phew.

So overall, we can't
reject the null hypothesis

of no difference
in survival curves

because the p-value
is not very small.

But as we've seen
in the course, this

doesn't mean necessarily
there is no difference.

It could mean that we
don't have much power
to find that difference.

Maybe our study wasn't
big enough in particular.
We had 88 patients.

Maybe if we had 8,000 patients,
there may be a difference.

88 patients in total, some were
censored, many were censored.
That's a good point.

The real sample size
in survival analysis

isn't so much the actual sample
size, but the number of events,

because the censored
observations

provide partial information,
but only a little bit.

They helped in the
denominators, but we were
counting the number of deaths.

Those were in the 30s total
and divided by two groups,
so quite small.

So it's always important to
remember the survival analysis,

the sample size isn't
quite what it seems.
So that's the log-rank test.

It's closely related to
Cox's proportional hazards
model, which we discuss next.

So we've seen the one sample
and how to summarize it
with a Kaplan-Meier.

We've seen the
two-sample problem

where we use a log-rank
test, and now we

move up to regression,
which is the more general,

more commonly
occurring situation.

So again, we have
our survival time

and we observe the minimum
of the actual survival
time and the censoring time.

Well, again, if
you think about it

as a regression, a
supervised learning problem,

we would be tempted
maybe to regress Y on X,

or maybe since Y has a
long right tail typically

being a survival
time, maybe log Y.

But again, the censoring
creates a problem.

We can't just do that
because we don't know
how to deal with the censoring.

So we're going to use a
sequential construction

similar to the idea used
in the Kaplan-Meier curve.

And you'll see this
coming up all the time
in survival analysis.

You think of it as a
process that unfolds in time

and you model it time
point by time point,
failure time by failure time.

So we've seen that for
Kaplan-Meier, we've

done that for log-rank
and now for regression.

One thing that's maybe worth
saying, the Kaplan-Meier curve,

it's like a distribution
function which you just

fit to your data,
in other words,

we say it's non-parametric,
it doesn't really

make any assumptions,
but it does take
into account the censoring.

And from that point of
view, it's attractive

And maybe why you
bring this in is

that the next method,
proportional hazards model,

we'll see right now,
carries that theme on.

Basically it's got sort of a
semi-parametric component, which

makes it quite
robust to departures
for modeling assumptions.
So let's see how this works.

So before we get
there, we need to learn

a new quantity, the hazard
rate or hazard function--
I warned you.

--also known as the
force of mortality.
So what is it?
Well, let's look at it.
It's a theoretical quantity.

This is a function of
the random variable T,

it's a probability that T falls
between t and t plus delta given

T is greater than t
as delta t goes to 0.

It's kind of a derivative,
but what it's saying

is it's a probability of
dying in the next instant

from now, given you've
survived up to this time.

And so that's why it's called
the force of mortality,

kind of a scary quantity for
people our age getting up there.

It turns out that if you know
the survival distribution,

you can just compute
this quantity.

It's just another way
of representing that.

So the SFT is actually,
as Trevor said,

there's a one-to-one
mapping between the hazard
and the survival function.

But this turns out to
be a convenient quantity

for the model that comes up
next, the proportional hazards
model.

And this is due to David Cox
in a very famous paper in 1972,

known as the proportional
hazards model.

OK, so what is a
proportional hazards model?

Again, the point of this
section is a regression now,

we want to model
covariates or features
and how they affect the outcome.
So there's our features, xij.

And xi is for observation
i and feature j.
We've got p such features.

Now we're going to
assume that the hazard

for an individual with
features xi at time t

is some what's called a
baseline hazard function, that's
unspecified, times this factor.

Well, what's the
exponential doing here?

Well, the hazard function has to
be positive, it's a probability.

So the exponential really
the main reason for it

there is to make this
a positive quantity.

So this hazard now
is a hazard function

for an individual
with features xi.

If x is 0, we get
the baseline hazard.

So what this is
saying is the hazard

for an individual who's
got certain feature is

some common hazard that
everybody has times

a factor which either
increases or decreases

his hazard depending on
whether the betas are
positive or negative.

And the beauty of this model
is that that common hazard,

we're not going to really make
too many assumptions about it.

It's just going to be sort of
like the Kaplan-Meier in a way.

It's going to be
a non-parametric.

Exactly, and we'll
see how that's
done in a couple of slides.

So this quantity is called the
relative risk for this feature
vector.

The relative risk, if we have
an individual with these feature

values compared to an individual
with all 0, that's the baseline,

the ratio of their hazards
is this second quantity.

That's why it's called
the relative risk.

If this is 1.2, for
example, it says

an individual with these
features is 1.2 times

is likely to die as an
individual with these feature
values.
In the next instance.
In the next, right.
Actually at all time.
At all times.

At all time, because
there's no T.
It doesn't on T.
Exactly.

And as we've said
and Trevor said,

that what this
model is saying is

it makes no assumptions
about the functional

form of the baseline
hazard, which is very nice.

It means it can adapt itself to
a lot of different situations

without having to specify
exactly the hazard
for a baseline individual.
It makes it flexible.

Again, the only assumption
is that the features come in

as a factor that increase or
decreases the relative risk

by a constant factor
depending on the parameters.

Of course, these
parameters are going

to estimate from data just
like we did in regression.

Rob, wasn't one of your
very first papers on Cox
proportional hazards model?
That's right.

When I was still a graduate
student and working

at a medical center, a
doctor I was working with
didn't understand the model.

He was British,
he said he should

write a very simple explanation
of proportional hazards.

So I wrote a paper
called a Plain Man's

Guide to the proportional
hazards model.
The lovely paper.

Actually I'm kind of
proud of it still.
I wasn't being facetious.
It really is lovely.
OK, so--
I should read it sometime.
No, just kidding.

So here's an example of
proportional hazards,

just to reinforce what
it's really saying.

Let's take the simplest case
where we have a single covariate
and it's 0, 1.

So it's a two-group case, maybe
males and females or whatever.

OK, here's the hazard function,
the log hazard functions

and the survival
probability for it

says here xi equals 0 is green
and xi equals 1 is black.

Proportional hazards means
the gap between these two log
hazards is a constant.

It also turns out to imply that
the survival curves don't cross.
And we see example here.

As time goes on, they get
farther and farther apart,
but they don't cross.

So the proportionality
is for the hazard,

the one on the left,
when you map it

back to the survival
function, it's

a different kind
of relationship.
Right.

It's in the book, but it's
a little more complicated.

Since the model is expressed
in terms of the hazard,

then on the log scale,
you see this constant gap.

Over here the gap
is not constant.
But it doesn't cross.

On the other hand, if we had
a situation like this where

the hazards cross, this group
is doing better for a while

and then worse later, then the
survival curves also cross.

And this is a non-proportional
hazard situation.

So proportional hazards
model without modification

can't really capture
this situation.

So it's a convenient assumption,
which is often reasonable.
It's often reasonable.
And there are ways to check it.

And we just talk
in the book a bit

about that and with references,
but it's a good starting model.
It's often very effective.
